results.headline: Seeking Aid for Autism in Mongolia
results.summary_short: “The Horse Boy” is a record of an extraordinary journey, a grueling weekslong trek across the plains of Mongolia in search of shamanic help.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Horse Boy

results.headline: Retracing the Path of a Candid Observer
results.summary_short: “An American Journey” is a movie about the making of a book, which puts it in a fairly narrow category.
results.display_title: An American Journey: Revisiting Robert Frank's "The Americans"

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of An American Journey: Revisiting Robert Frank's "The Americans"

results.headline: A Woman for Every Zodiac Sign
results.summary_short: Ashutosh Gowariker’s new movie, an adaptation of a Gujarati novel by Madhu Rye, is epic in length only.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of What's Your Raashee?

results.headline: In Space No One Can Hear You Eat Flesh
results.summary_short: “Pandorum” may sound like a disease suffered by fuzzy black-and-white mammals, but the only fuzziness in this apocalyptic nightmare is between the characters’ ears.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Pandorum

results.headline: Avatars and Their Meat-Puppeteers
results.summary_short: In “Surrogates,” Bruce Willis has little to do but hit his predictable marks and mouth the generic dialogue.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Surrogates

results.headline: Unrelenting Hard Work
results.summary_short: More an infomercial than a movie, “The Providence Effect” is, at best, a well-earned tribute to one man’s unwavering vision.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Providence Effect

results.headline: More Boys, More Beer, More Banter
results.summary_short: “I Hope They Serve Beer in Hell” is a mediocre gross-out movie that barely pushes the envelope.
results.display_title: I Hope They Serve Beer in Hell

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of I Hope They Serve Beer in Hell

results.headline: Another Optimistic Bunch, Determined to Live Forever
results.summary_short: While “Fame” suffers from a surfeit of flash, it nonetheless offers the undeniable power of young performers pursuing art at peak dexterity.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Fame

results.headline: The Unsentimental Education That Preceded a Life of Fashion
results.summary_short: With a mixture of brutal candor and tender sympathy, “Coco Before Chanel” charts the rise of an ambitious, difficult woman.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Coco Before Chanel

results.headline: How Are Guys Flawed? Let Us Count the Ways
results.summary_short: What do men want? This reversal of Freud’s famous question drives John Krasinski’s “Brief Interviews With Hideous Men” into a blind alley.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Brief Interviews With Hideous Men

results.headline: A One-Parent, No-Rules Household
results.summary_short: “The Boys Are Back” has a burnished, high-quality look and a heart swollen with maudlin self-regard.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Boys Are Back

results.headline: Writing a Scriptwriter’s Life
results.summary_short: “The Blue Tooth Virgin” starts out feeling a little too “inside Hollywood” and only grows more so as it rolls along.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Blue Tooth Virgin

results.headline: Alternative Possibilities
results.summary_short: While “Blind Date” does not quite work as psychological inquiry or cogent drama, it is an interesting project.

results.headline: Episodes That Offer Questions, Not Answers
results.summary_short: Michael Almereyda’s “Paradise” is essentially a series of home movies, but home movies of a very high order.

results.headline: A Foray Into Female Obsessions
results.summary_short: “Irene in Time” is a loose-limbed conversation about daddies, daughters and emotional damage.

results.headline: Greed Is Good? He Begs to Differ
results.summary_short: “Capitalism: A Love Story” sees Michael Moore cracking jokes, milking tears and taking aim at the financial system.

results.headline: A Look at a Revolutionary Composer
results.summary_short: The best thing about “In Search of Beethoven,” Phil Grabsky’s biography of the composer, is the company he brings along on the hunt.

results.headline: Cross-Dressing to Go to Bat for India and for Love, Too
results.summary_short: In “Dil Bole Hadippa!” a woman dresses as a man in order to play on her local cricket team, which just happens to represent India in a yearly match against Pakistan.

results.headline: A Corporate Culture Cornfed on Greed
results.summary_short: “The Informant!” is a smart, cynical movie about how we buy now — oops, I mean, how we live now.
